C 434/72 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 EN Court observations The coordination and representation of the KICs is carried out by the legal entities of the KICs, which are financed almost entirely by the Institute.
The Court paid particular attention to the procurement procedures carried out by these bodies, which it considers to be a highly risky area.
In accordance with the 2015 grant agreements, the legal entities of the KICs and/or the KIC partners must ensure that the best possible price-performance ratio is achieved in procurement or that the lowest-price criterion is applied where appropriate.
For all contracts of more than EUR 60 000, the legal persons of the KICs and/or the KIC partners shall, according to the grant agreements, require at least three economic operators to tender and document the award procedure to demonstrate its transparency.
The Court carried out a sample of procurement procedures worth around EUR 7 million, carried out by the legal entities of the KIC and financed entirely by the EIT.
The investigation revealed significant differences, such as direct award of contracts, absence of essential elements in tenders, significant extensions of original contracts in terms of duration and/or size, additions without limitation of duration and/or scope, or quality/price weightings, which led to price competition.
The Institute also identified the M:ngels in the procurement procedures of a KIC legal entity and drew up an action plan to improve the procurement procedures of all KIC legal entities in the future.
Despite the substantial increase in the budget from EUR 309 million (2008-2013) to EUR 2.4 billion (2014-2020) and despite the fact that there have been six KICs since the end of 2016 and no longer three KICs as before, the number of posts allocated to the Institute has barely changed (see Table 2).
As the Court noted in its Special Report No 4/2016 (9), there is a risk that the Institute will not have sufficient capacity to address the increased workload.
The interim director of the institute pointed to this risk in the annual report of the institute for 2015.

EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/73 REPLY OF THE INSTITUTE 3.9.7.
The EIT should make it clear that changes to the individual grant agreements pursuant to the KIC Framework Partnership Agreements of the EIT can be submitted at any time during the promotion period.
The KICs' amendments were subject to a technical and financial evaluation by the EIT and prior approval by the European Commission.
Subsequently, the changes were signed in December 2016.
In the case of EIT Climate-KIC, the KIC was formally notified of the approval of the amendment request on 21 December 2016 (i.e. within the period of application).
As regards the increase in individual reimbursements, the EIT points out that the KICs did not receive any additional financial assistance as a result of the changes to the individual financial assistance agreements in 2016.
The total amount of the final financial assistance (241.8 million euros) was significantly lower than the initial amount (274.9 million euros).
As regards the call for KICs to develop their own sources of financing and to become financially viable, we refer to our response to section 3.9.15.
In the context of the assessment of the change proposals, the EIT, after consultation with the European Commission, concluded that the adjustment of each refund measure corresponds to the applicable legal basis and does not affect the equal treatment of KICs.
The possibility of adjusting the individual refund rates was open to all KICs on equal terms.
As regards the second observation, the EIT considers that the amendments corresponded to Article 180(4) of the Financial Regulation, since they did not call into question the decisions on the award of grants and did not run counter to equal treatment of applicants.
It should be noted that there is no provision for a materiality threshold, which shows which change of a measure in the assessment whether the change for the grant is relevant is to be regarded as significant.
Whether the inclusion of new activities corresponds to that provision must be established on a case-by-case basis on the basis of the relevance and impact of the activities for the entire KIC business plan.
The EIT carried out the assessment prior to the approval of the change proposals and concluded that the changes did not call into question the decisions on the award of grants.
Since each KIC had the ability to include new independent activities in its changed businesses on equal terms, the equal treatment of KIC was also ensured.
Finally, the EIT points out that in the case of EIT InnoEnergy, the only activity in question was only 3.9% of the modified budget estimate of the KIC's business plan.
For EIT Digital, this proportion was 0.6%.

3.9.12.
The updated versions of the contingency plan and the plan for re-commissioning following a system breakdown are adopted by the EIT in 2018.
3.9.13.
The 2016 individual financial assistance agreements with EIT Health and EIT RawMaterials were signed later than planned as the framework partnership agreements had to be signed first.
The individual grant agreements for 2017 and 2018 were systematically signed in February, so that the KICs were able to take up their activities in good time each year.
Due to their dynamic and fast-moving nature, innovative measures cannot be planned linearly.
Some innovation projects or projects do not meet the expectations of their potential and must be discontinued during the implementation of the grant agreements. Moreover, some of the operational activities of the KICs, such as master's and doctoral studies or long-term research and innovation projects, are planned from the ground up for several years.
The EIT intends to address this issue after 2020 by entering into multi-annual grant agreements with KICs, provided that the EIT budget allocates corresponding appropriations for commitments in multi-annual tranches.
In fact, the EIT has followed the methodology laid down in the legal basis ăHorizont 2020 and will continue to comply with the current legislation.
The financial sustainability of KIC is a unique ambition of the EIT-KIC model and one of the most difficult aspects of the EIT's mission.
In the meantime, some of the innovation communities are already able to provide substantial co-financing to meet their needs and generate considerable revenue compared to their budgets.
EIT Digital, for example, co-financed 26% (22 million euros) to cover the costs for the 2016 KIC value-added activities. In addition, the partner organisations carried out and paid additional KIC activities of more than 200 million euros.
Another example is EIT Health: In its first year of operation, KIC generated over EUR 6 million in revenue compared to the total funding it had received from the EIT (around EUR 19 million).

EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/75 3.10.
EUROPEAN AGENCY FOR THE SAFETY OF SEA TRANSPORT (EMSA) INTRODUCTION 3.10.1.
The European Maritime Safety Agency (hereinafter referred to as the Agency), based in Lisbon, was established by Regulation (EC) No 1406/2002 of the European Parliament and of the Council (92).
The Agency's tasks include the achievement of a high level of maritime safety, the prevention of ship pollution, the technical assistance of the Member States and the Commission, and the monitoring of the application of Union legislation and the assessment of its effectiveness.
3.10.2.
The table contains the main figures for the Agency (93).

COMMENTS ON INTERNAL CONTROLS 3.10.8.
In 2014, the Commission concluded a framework agreement with a contractor on the acquisition of software licenses and maintenance and support services on behalf of more than 50 EU institutions and bodies (including the Agency).
The contractor of the framework agreement acts as intermediary between the agency and companies that can meet the needs of the agency.
For these intermediate services, the contractor of the framework agreement adds two to nine percent to the supplier prices. In 2017, the contractor of the framework agreement paid a total of 1.7 million euros.
The Agency did not systematically compare the calculated prices and deadlines with the offers of the companies and also did not systematically check the invoices issued to the contractor of the framework agreement. COMMENTS ON THE ECONOMICITY OF BUDGETARY CURRENCY AND SERVICES 3.10.9. The Agency publishes job advertisements on its own website and on social media, but not on the website of the European Personnel Selection Office (EPSO).
3.10.10.
In accordance with its framework financial regulation, the agencies should establish a uniform framework for the electronic storage and exchange of data with third parties involved in procurement procedures (96) (97). As a corresponding requirement also applies to the EU institutions, the Commission is currently developing an overall IT system covering all stages of public procurement procedures.
It launched tools for electronic invoicing (2010), electronic publication of documents on contract notices in the Official Journal of the EU (2011) and electronic submission of tenders (2015).

30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/77 EN ANNEX Follow-up to comments from previous years Statements by the Court In 2014, the Agency concluded a six-year framework contract worth EUR 3.5 million for the acquisition of goods and services in the IT sector.
The agency supported the demand and expected order value, which meant that the contract was 80% off at the end of 2016.
A new procurement procedure must be launched four years earlier than expected, which will lead to additional administrative costs.
In 2016, the Agency completed seven framework contracts for the acquisition of pollution control systems.
Each framework contract (each lot in the procurement procedure) referred to a specific selection.
The award procedure was initiated in the assumption that the total value of the seven framework contracts would be EUR 7 million.
However, with this assumption, the Agency's needs were supported, and seven framework contracts were signed, each amounting to EUR 7 million, resulting in a total value of EUR 49 million.
Year 2016 2016 State of adoption of the correction (completed/in progress/outgoing/ n.e.c.) n.e.c.
EN C 434/78 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 REPLY OF THE AGENCY 3.10.8.
The Agency will remind the responsible project managers to consistently carry out the necessary checks on the prices charged by the provider and/or to verify whether the correct deadlines are applied.
EMSA will also invite the leading public contracting authority in this framework agreement to ask the contractor regularly to always attest the market price/addition when responding to offer requirements.
3.10.9.
Following a court decision, the EPSO decided that only job advertisements can be published on the EPSO website in the official languages of the EU or in the languages indicated in the Agency's legislative act.
Due to the high translation costs of this new policy (about EUR 19000 per advertised post), EMSA and many other agencies no longer use EPSO services in their job advertisements.
This issue was raised by some agencies in December 2015 against the EPSO.
EMSA would like to see a solution which offers both sufficient transparency and complies with the principle of sound financial management.
The Agency aims to promote its job advertisements to a broad audience by distributing them on various social media used by many people.
It should be noted that most of EMSA's job advertisements are addressed to technical professionals who regularly access the EMSA website.
In 2017, EMSA made extensive preparations for adapting all internal procedures to the use of e-procurement.
EMSA is able to confirm that it has been introducing the modules for electronic procurement since the beginning of 2018.
The deadline for the use of electronic procurement by EU bodies is October 2018.

DE ANNEX Follow-up of observations from previous years Statements by the Court The Agency plans to transfer administrative staff from Heraklion to Athens in 2016.
The rate of committed appropriations carried over to the following financial year is high for Title II (administrative expenditure) at EUR 0.3 million and 25% (2015: EUR 0.15 million and 22%).
This high rate is mainly due to transfers of funds under Title I (staff expenditure) and Title III (operational expenditure) and is primarily linked to IT investments made shortly before the end of the year and the acquisition of a service car.
As foreseen in the Agency's financial rules, external evaluations of the Agency's performance for 2014 and 2015 were carried out; the final reports were submitted in October 2015 and May 2016 respectively.
The 2014 evaluation concluded that the operational core activities carried out under the 2014 Work Programme had a clear link with the Agency's legal mandate and that the Agency's effectiveness was well assessed.
However, there was a need for improvement in the division of the Agency between Heraklion and Athens, which leads to difficult work and a lack of communication and cooperation.
The 2015 evaluation concluded that the Agency's activities and outputs meet a need for network and information security throughout the EU and in the Member States and that the Agency effectively meets the expectations of its stakeholders.
However, the report stressed that the communication between the Agency and its stakeholders, who believe that the mandate and scope of the Agency are too limited, needs to be improved.
The Agency is currently implementing an action plan which it has subsequently agreed with the Management Board.
In 2016, the Agency moved eight more employees to Athens, reducing the number of employees in Heraklion to 14 (1).
As the Court pointed out in its 2013 report, costs could probably be further reduced by pooling all staff at one location.

COMMENTS ON THE EXISTENCE OF THE CURRENCY OF ACCOUNTS 3.12.8.
In December 2016, the Agency's accountant was appointed interim manager of the Financial and Procurement Department in addition to this function.
In the context of this additional function, it is responsible for the management of staff, which is responsible for the introduction and supervision of commitments and payments.
The financial rules of the Agency stipulate that those financial operators are under the authority of the authorising officer.
However, according to the principle of separation of duties, powers of instruction and accounting are separate functions and exclude each other.
In 2014, the Commission concluded a framework agreement with a contractor on the acquisition of IT hardware and software, as well as maintenance and support services (IT services), on behalf of more than 50 EU institutions and bodies (including the Agency).
In the event of a paid payment of about 47 000 euros, the agency had acquired IT services from the contractor without competitive process or prior market analysis. In 2017, payments to the contractor were made in amount of 1.1 million euros.

Although the under-representations have different dimensions (2014: non-compliance with the guaranteed minimum income; 2015: application of a false multiplication factor to the beneficiaries), the Court once again noted too low expenditures (43350 euros) and some over-representations (168930 euros), which concerned 30 active and earlier employees.

AGENCY FOR THE EUROPEAN GNSS (GLOBAL SATELLITE NAVIGATION SYSTEM) (GSA) INTRODUCTION 3.16.1.
The Agency for the European GNSS (global satellite navigation system) (hereinafter referred to as the Agency), whose seat was moved from Brussels to Prague on 1 September 2012, was created by Regulation (EU) No 912/2010 of the European Parliament and of the Council (132) repealing Council Regulation (EC) No 1321/2004 (133) on the administrative bodies of the European satellite navigation programmes and amending Regulation (EC) No 683/2008 of the European Parliament and of the Council(134).
The European GNSS Authority, set up under Council Regulation (EC) No 1321/2004, officially carried out on 1 January 2007 all the tasks previously entrusted to the Galileo Joint Undertaking. e Agency continues to carry out these tasks as an agency for the European GNSS on the basis of Regulation (EU) No 912/2010, as amended.
In addition, the Commission commissioned the Agency to operate the European Geostationary Navigation Overlay System (EGNOS) by means of a transfer agreement.

Emphasis on a case 3.16.7.
On 15 December 2016, the Agency concluded a framework agreement worth EUR 1.5 billion on the operation of the Galileo satellite system during the period 2017-2027.
The agreement was awarded following a public procurement procedure.
One of the tenderers involved brought proceedings against the Agency before the Court of Justice of the European Union in order to challenge the outcome of the award procedure.
The judgment of the Court of Justice of the European Union will decide on the legality and regularity of the procurement procedure for the framework agreement and all related individual contracts and future payments.
The Agency has reported the facts in the previous annual accounts 2017 and has explained and further indicated that in 2017 49 million euros (7 % of the budget of 2017 including the amounts received by the transfer agreements) were paid out in connection with the framework agreement.

The Agency operates both the Galileo Security Centre (GSMC) and Galileo ground stations in the United Kingdom.

The accounting systems were last validated in 2012.

The late adoption of central planning documents entails risks for the achievement of the Agency's objectives.

In its November 2016 audit report, the Commission's Internal Audit Service (IAS) concluded that no agency-wide annual risk assessment was carried out in 2016 and that the significant risks for the Agency are not mentioned in its planning documents or in its activity reports.
In addition, the IAS noted that the terminology used for the various elements of the performance measurement system is not uniform, making performance monitoring more difficult.
The Agency and IAS agreed on a plan for corrective measures. At 2.8 million euros or 46% (2015: 2.5 million euros or 42%), the rate of committed appropriations for Title II (administrative expenditure) for the following financial year was high.
EN C 434/102 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 REPLY OF THE AGENCY 3.16.10.
The GSA agrees with the Court's comment.
In 2015, the GSA outsourced its accounts to the European Commission, so that the Commission's accounting officer (within DG Budget) provides all the services, including the validation of local systems, required under Article 50 of the framework financial regulation applicable to the agencies.
The validation approach is currently being developed and planned within DG Budget services.
3.16.11.
The publication of job advertisements on the EPSO platform requires translation into all EU official languages, whereas English is the Agency's only working language, and the publication of vacancies in English is considered a first step in preselection to ensure that our working language is first understood.
In addition, the translation of job advertisements into all EU official languages would mean an additional financial and time-consuming effort for the agency, so that there is no benefit from it even from the above reasons. Instead, the GSA intends to publish all job advertisements on the agency's cross-border portal, which the agencies consider equivalent to the EPSO and offers the EU citizens a sufficient amount of transparency.
In addition, the agency also publishes its job advertisements on specialized space websites.
Electronic communications in TED (published by the Office for Publications) are currently used in the GSA for the publication of contract notices, award notices, notices on corrections, modification notices, etc. whenever this is indicated in accordance with Article 264 of the applicable provisions.
The Agency also intends to use the e-Tendering system TED to create and publish tenders.
Against this background, the GSA is currently coordinating with the Office for Publications to register and create a system account.
With regard to offers of high value (above the thresholds of Article 118(1) HO), the GSA is currently undertaking the necessary administrative steps to use the ăe Submission module of the information system ăe-PRIOR (made available by DG DIGIT) developed by the European Commission in order to ensure that the electronic system set up for the submission of all offers meets all the requirements of HO and AB.
It is noted that the module ăe-Submission is currently supported exclusively by open procedures and the GSA is therefore allowed to use it only for such procedures.
In this context, the GSA has already held an initial coordination meeting with DG DIGIT and is in the process of concluding and signing an agreement with it in order to define and start implementing the framework for ăe Submission.

COMMENTS ON THE EFFECTIVENESS OF BUDGETARY AFFAIRS AND SERVICES 3.17.9.
The Agency welcomes the fact that the Court wishes to further improve its management of the ETZ both in terms of financial and operational controls.
In order to re-examine the problem that occurred at the ETZ in 2017, internal, coastal and marine waters, the task in question was removed from the annual action plan and transferred to the Agency.
The Agency is committed to maintaining the current level of control of grants granted to the ETZ.
The Agency confirms that it has changed the requirements relating to the financial performance of bidders in the course of 2017 and that the bidders are now required to provide information on financial indicators (liquidity, solvency and profitability); furthermore, in accordance with the provisions of Article 147(1)(a) of the Rules of Application (AB), a minimum turnover is now required which must be at least twice the value of the estimated annual contract value.
The Agency would like to stress once again that the decision to offer framework contracts to individual contractors has been taken consciously and taking into account the fact that competition is limited to the relevant markets, as well as the nature and complexity of the services to be provided.
When awarding individual contracts on the basis of the framework contracts, the Agency not only takes into account the contractually agreed days, but also the number of days required for the execution of tasks in order to calculate a value for the budget to be used for a specific individual contract.
Only then will negotiations be opened with the contractor about the details of his offer, always paying attention to achieving the best price-performance ratio.
In the event of a resumption of the tender, the Agency has no control over further negotiations on the bids of the tenderers.
In accordance with the decision of the Management Board of 9 November 2015 to introduce an electronic invoicing system in the EEA for the electronic handling of the procurement procedures, the Agency introduced certain procedures for electronic invoicing in the course of 2014 and is now in the process of extending the application of this module to all its procedures, whereas the electronic tendering procedure has been in force for all general invitations to tender since 1 January 2015.
The integration of the electronic submission of tenders was launched at the beginning of December 2017, and the first call for tenders for this module was launched on 18 June 2018 (EEA/COM/18/002 
The Agency takes note of the Court's remark and confirms that it is currently adapting its selection/ recruitment procedures to the following points: a) The completion of the individual steps in the different phases (pre-selection, selection, interview and written examination) is confirmed in the relevant documents in addition with the time indication (not only with the date). b) An electronic (paperless) procedure is introduced in order to improve the reporting process.
3.17.14.
The EPSO has rejected a publication for the agency with the view that the precondition that all job offers are to be translated into all official languages is not fulfilled.
The Agency, however, has neither the resources nor the resources to respond to the request of the EPSO.
In this case, not only all job offers should be translated, but the applications should also be processed in all the official languages, which is associated with unsustainable additional costs.
As with most other EU agencies, the Agency has therefore looked for an alternative to the EPSO website and has been using a website that fulfils the same purpose since May 2018 for its announcements; it is the job advertisement board set up and maintained by the network of EU agencies.
In addition, the agency uses LinkedIn, its own website and Facebook pages to ensure the best possible distribution.
EN C 434/108 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 COMMENTS ON THE BUDGETARY CURRENCY 3.17.15.

First of all, DG GROW was very clear in its reply, but DG BUDG, responsible for drafting the standard template, refused to change the transfer agreement.
Following the start of the implementation of the transfer agreement, the Agency continued to point out the problems and stated that it is regularly obliged to apply exceptions in order to continue its operational activity; this prompted DG GROW to change the pre-financing conditions of the transfer agreement in August 2017 and to make additional pre-financing in November 2017.

Payments Basis for the failure to give a ruling on the legality and regularity of the payments underlying the annual accounts 3.20.6.
Paragraphs 3.20.9-3.20.31 describe essential and systematic provisions against the financial regulations of the company, as well as other rules and provisions concerning payments. Payments made in connection with procurement and recruitment procedures were particularly affected.
The cumulative error due to the irregular payments concerns at least 7.7 million euros or 10.3% of the total payments made by the B sucho in 2017.

According to our assessment, the payments underlying the annual accounts for the financial year ending 31 December 2017 are error-prone due to the importance of the facts described in the ăBase for the failed judgment on the legality and regularity of the payments underlying the annual accounts.
Emphasis on a point of view 3.20.8.
From the end of 2017, the personnel situation at the B的ro deteriorated exponentially.
At management level, four out of ten Head of Unit posts and 18 out of 27 Head of Division posts were not filled.
Three out of four Head of Unit posts and five out of ten Head of Division posts were not filled in the Administration Department, which represents a serious challenge for the management level of the agency.
Furthermore, at the end of May 2018, 129 posts were filled for temporary staff, but 78 were still open.
Of the posts for contract staff, 71 were occupied and 13 were still open.
The B sucho does not currently have the administrative capacity to fill so many vacancies (see Table 2).
Overall, the continuation of the activities of the B-ros is considerably affected by this situation to the present extent.
EN C 434/118 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 Table 2 Organizational chart of the European Union beginning of June 2018
EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/119 COMMENTS ON LEGAL ACTIVITY AND ORDER ACTIVITY OF PAYMENTS AND THE INTERNAL CONTROLS OF CORRESPONSIBILITY The nature of its activities gives rise to large risks for the company 3.20.9.
Since 2016, the B sucho has been faced with an unprecedented expansion of tasks and activities to provide operational and technical support to Member States in the context of the migration crisis.
This is reflected in an increase in the budget from the original EUR 19 million in 2016 to EUR 79 million following the second change in the 2017 budget.
The number of procurement procedures increased from 87 in 2015 to 140 in 2017.
Payments increased by 225% from 2 578 in 2015 to 8 381 in 2017.
3.20.10.
The B-ro is one of the few institutions of the European Union that has several locations.
In addition to its headquarters in Malta with 179 staff members, the company manages two major support actions in Greece and Italy, involving 747 experts from Member States and associated countries, 202 cultural mediators (interpreters), 178 temporary workers and 21 staff members of the association.
3.20.11.
As the Court has already stated in its Special Report No. 6/2017 ăReaction of the EU to the refugee crisis: the Hotspot concept, the B-ro is highly dependent on the Member States providing sufficient resources.
The efficiency of the activities is particularly affected by the fact that Member States send their experts for a very short period of time (six to eight weeks).
The extraordinary operational challenge posed by the migration crisis was not weakened by a sound management structure and effective internal controls 3.20.12.
When the activities to support Greece and Italy were introduced in 2015, the B'ro was confronted with the fact that Member States provided insufficient resources for deployments.
Before that, the Bureau had already had difficulty filling the posts provided for in its establishment plan.
Since 2014, the court has regularly repeated its remark that the B-ro has to struggle with a high staff turnover.
The Court has repeatedly stressed in its previous annual reports that this situation represents a serious risk for achieving the objectives set out in the annual and multiannual work programmes.
Despite repeated attempts (36 recruitment procedures and 100 new assignments in 2017), the company did not manage to recruit and maintain employees (see also paragraph 3.20.8).
3.20.13.
The extraordinary challenge in the operational area caused by the migration crisis was not weakened by a solid management structure.
The Board of Directors did not set up an internal audit post at the office, and the actions in Greece and Italy were not subject to an internal audit.
By the end of 2017, the Board of Directors had limited supervision over the budget.
3.20.14.
In the case of the B的ro, neither an internal legal service is established nor legal documents are systematically internized.
The B:ro assigns most of the legal questions (mainly personnel and procurement questions) to outside, without having clearly defined in internal decisions or guidelines, who may assign which legal questions externally, to which law firm and under what conditions.
Although the company uses at least eight different law firms, it lacks a comprehensive list of all relevant departments, cases and expert opinions.
3.20.15.
Legal services are not adequately provided by the B:ro to ensure that they are exclusively used to defend the interests of the B:ro and not to defend the interests of individuals.
The relevant procedures to protect against conflicts of interest are not always effective.
In general, the use of external means reduces the possibility of settling disputes before bringing an action.
3.20.16.
The facts set out in paragraphs 3.20.13-3.20.14 expose the bank to the risk of financial losses and distortions of reputation.
These matters are currently being examined internally by the B.O.O.
Many essential obligations against regulations resulting from lack of internal controls Payments for auxiliary services 3.20.17.
In 2017, €7.7 million was paid for auxiliary services.
Since no competitive public procurement procedure had taken place, the Court found the order for auxiliary services in Greece to be contrary to the law in respect of the year 2016.
Nevertheless, the B sucho still made payments of EUR 4.8 million in 2017 within the framework of this illegal order.
EN C 434/120 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 3.20.18.
The procurement procedures for auxiliary services carried out in Malta in 2017 (volume of payments in 2017: 1.0 million euros) were inadequate in their execution (e.g. short deadlines for the submission of tenders, lack of transparency in the extension of deadlines), which made the competition one of the most important reasons for the public procurement procedures.
As a result, the procedures had to be repeated several times because no tenders were received.
3.20.19.
The contributions were insufficiently controlled for compliance with the national regulations for temporary employment, which exposed the company to significant financial and reputational risks.
Furthermore, the over-preparation of working time certificates for auxiliary staff and established irregularities showed considerable weaknesses.
Payments for staff expenditure 3.20.20.
The personnel-related payments amounted to 13.5 million euros in 2017. The Court found serious errors in four of the 14 recruitment procedures.
3.20.21.
For example, the B-ro did not publish a job advertisement to fill the post of senior consultant, but did the recruitment directly on the basis of a reserve list drawn up for the post of head of department.
The extension of the deadline was not always justified in view of the number of applications received by the original deadline.
3.20.22.
Some procedures for hiring AD staff were not suitable for the advertised grade.
In the case of a procedure for filling a management post in the ăVerwaltungstung (administrative department), the job advertisement was more restrictive than in the case of the same posts in other departments.
In another procedure, the examination of the suitability of the applicants was not adequately documented by the B-ro.
Payments for rents and related works 3.20.23.
The total rent for all the bikes at the different locations amounted to two million euros in 2017.
The Court noted that the B sucho had signed the rental contracts for the extension of the headquarters in Malta and several new B suchos in Athens, Lesbos and Chios without having previously adequately analysed the local market.
3.20.24.
In June 2017, the B sucho signed a lease on B suchofling in Lesbos.
It also accepted a contract with the landlord - without any competition ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The value of the contract (0.7 million euros during the first months of the contract) exceeded the annual value of the contract by many times.
The investment of significant investments in rented buildings is accompanied by serious financial and operational risks.
3.20.25.
In 2018, the B sucho decided to contract a rental contract with B suchoflachen in Chios and related construction services.
It is currently designed to limit the financial risk exposure caused by the suspension.
Travel expenses 3.20.26.
The Court held at its review in 2016 an order for travel services worth 4 million euros against the rules.
The contract was awarded to a bidder who did not meet all the selection criteria.
On the basis of this illegal order, the company continued to make payments of 1.5 million dollars in 2017.
3.20.27.
In 2017, the B sucho identified significant errors in the recognition of travel services, in particular the lack of evidence to demonstrate that the travel services concerned were actually requested or provided.
This matter is currently being examined internally by the B.O.O.
Other payments 3.20.28.
In addition, other services such as cleaning services, security services, interpreting and consulting services, which were based on public procurement procedures, were systematically affected by the same rules.
The Court identified significant shortcomings in the assessment of demand for the product, the preparation of specifications, the choice of the type of contract, the award procedures applied, the time limits for submission of tenders, the evaluation and award procedures (i.e. the weighting of price criteria against quality criteria), the changes and extensions of contracts, the execution of contracts and the supervision of the services provided.
These rules have an impact on the basic principles of competition, transparency, equal treatment and non-discrimination of bidders.
The following digits contain some examples for the above mentioned angels.
EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/121 3.20.29.
In 2017, the B的ro awarded a service contract on advisory services in connection with the implementation of the Action Plan on the Greek islands.
The contract was awarded to an economic operator selected in advance without any of the procurement procedures provided for in the Financial Regulation being applied.
The award procedure and all related payments (EUR 992000) were therefore unlawful.
3.20.30.
The B sucho has changed the original contract of 5000 euros concluded in 2016 with a law firm several times since then and increased it to 259000 euros in 2018.
The contract was paid in cash in 2017 of a total of EUR 98332, partly for consultancy services, which required a competitive public procurement procedure.
The changes and payments relating to these advisory services were therefore contrary to the rules.
3.20.31.
The execution of the contract concluded in 2013 (value: 120 000 euros, raised in 2017 to 132 000 euros) about the organization of four to six major events in an international hotel for a period of four years was not in line with the original subject of the contract.
The B sucho used the contract instead for about 50 smaller events.
The execution of the contract has therefore not been carried out in accordance with the law.
COMMENTS ON BUDGETARY CURRENCY 3.20.32.
In accordance with the agreements concluded between the European Union and the Kingdom of Norway, the Swiss Confederation and the Principality of Liechtenstein (also referred to as associated countries) regarding their participation in the project, the associated countries are fully involved in the work of the project and are entitled to the support measures of the project.
In 2016, the B-ro received financial assistance from the Commission to ensure adequate capacity building in Greece, support the implementation of the declaration of the European Union and Turkey, and significantly accelerate redistribution in order to reduce the current high burden for Greece.
All these activities are part of the core business of the B such as the support of measures of common interest.
The B-ro used the financial support for payments (EUR 6.4 million in 2016 and EUR 1.7 million in 2017) of commitments made in connection with these activities.
However, it did not include these interests in the calculation of the contributions of the associated countries.
If these contributions were included, the associated countries would have to pay EUR 0.5 million more.

30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/123 Court's observations A framework agreement with a duration of two months with a value of 3.6 million euros on auxiliary services in connection with the settlement of the migration crisis was awarded directly by the bank in February 2016.
The framework contract was awarded to a pre-selected economic operator without any of the procurement procedures provided for in the EU Financial Regulation being applied. However, there were no local staff to meet this demand. Furthermore, the confirmation of the Greek authorities that the equipment was delivered to the hotspots in February and the beginning of March 2016 and that it was assigned to its intended purpose was not received until July 2017.

DE C 434/126 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 REPLY OF THE ROS The B的ro thanks the Court for the very helpful report.
At the same time, the Court is grateful for its appreciation of the difficult situation in which the Court found itself in the period under review as a result of the enormous expansion of its tasks: it has also been charged with supporting the Member States and participating in the implementation of initiatives at EU level, including redistribution and the declaration of EU-Turkey, an increase in the budget, the exponential increase in payments and the increase in procurement procedures (both in terms of number and complexity).
In addition, the company has to manage a large number of sites and many management positions (department heads, department heads, sector heads) are not filled.
In its present reply, the Court will comment on some of the Court's observations, but overall it accepts the report and the findings contained in it.
3.20.6. and 3.20.13.
With regard to the systematic understandings against the regulations in the "B"ro, the "B"ro "" under the new direction "" has begun with the introduction of the necessary steps to ensure that the observance of the regulations takes precedence and becomes the central element of culture and in the implementation of all its measures.
This includes objective, honest and open internal control, self-assessment.
The Court accepts the Court's finding that the monitoring structures and internal control structures responsible by the Court have in the past not received the attention necessary to ensure adequate legality and regularity.
Here too, the Committee would like to note that the structure and procedures of the system will have absolute priority for the systematic achievement of justice and regularity (and corresponding pr-enzise and comprehensive reporting) under the new leadership.
3.20.6., 3.20.8. and 3.20.12.
The Court rightly underlines the fact that the human resources situation in the country has deteriorated and is insufficient and that it is also an obstacle to the proper functioning of the internal control system.
The current human resources situation is one of the major challenges associated with the resolution of the angels identified by the Court in its remarks, which can largely be seen as a result of the lack of resources for structured and regular work.
The Bureau directly addresses this problem and, on the basis of a well-founded recruitment plan that has led to a need assessment, is urgently conducting recruitment procedures to fill management posts and other important (operational and administrative) posts.
In addition, the company makes efforts in the area of employee satisfaction in order to solve the problem of staff turnover. Although it is necessary to take into account the fact that the low correction coefficient plays an important role compared to the relatively high cost of living in Malta, the company acknowledges that more efforts must be made to improve employee satisfaction.
Some measures such as flexible work possibilities, improved internal communication and organisation of employee events have already been introduced.
3.20.9. and 3.20.19.
The Court gives a correct description of the difficulties and the rapid increase in financial transactions and procurement procedures, expressed in absolute figures.
These figures speak a clear language, but basically reflect the balances between finance and the awarding of contracts.
These figures do not take into account any other facts and measures which add to the compulsory situation in the procurement sector, such as the following two aspects: the involvement of externally funded experts (Articles 204 and 287 of the Financial Regulations), which represents a high workload for the procurement sector.
In the coming years, further deterioration is to be expected in this respect, as the medical experts must be drawn to the support of tasks related to medical information about countries of origin.
- Market-specific difficulties and restrictions related to our geographical areas of activity.
In the Italian and Greek regions, conditions for a competitive market for the provision of services and products are not very good.
In addition, the company is not typical as a customer in relation to the order size of the economic operators in Malta, since they mostly lack the capacity to meet the requirements associated with more extensive sales of the company.
3.20.10.-3.20.12. and 3.20.19.
This feature is essential for the understanding of verhtnism, which is a great effort for administrative support and the very complex environment when it comes to implementing functioning internal control structures.
It should also be noted that, due to its operational capacity, its geographically wide-spread area of operation and (as the Court rightly points out) the restrictions on the use of Member State experts are dependent on contractors on an unusually large scale.
This is a factor which is responsible for multiplying the tasks associated with the procurement and financial sector (including decentralised financial actors), as for places of operation in Greece, Italy and Cyprus.
EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/127 as well as for hotspots in Greece and Italy are required for each specific purpose (leasing vertebrae, cleaning, safety, water supply and for example for the provision of auxiliary and interpreting services).
In this case, too, the personnel have a decisive role to play, and the company is currently (in recognition of the multiplication factor due to its capacity as a multi-site agency) the ability to allocate the necessary resources to ensure overall accuracy and quality in the award and financial cycles, as well as legality and regularity, and to have the decentralisation carried out by a consulting firm.
3.20.14, 3.20.15 and 3.20.16.
The B-ro acknowledges the need to have internal legal expertise, and accepts this need.
In addition, the report fully agrees with the conclusion that legal services must always be strictly represented by the interests of the boss and not the interests of individuals (but this does not exclude each other).
The B的ro r的umts that the inclusion of external legal services has not been adequately controlled.
As the Court notes in its report, the internal investigations will continue on this matter and the results will be communicated to the Court.
3.20.17. and 3.20.26.
The B sucho accepts the comments.
These remedies were immediately initiated after the Court found the irregularity in its 2016 audit report (initiation of the Court's report in September 2017).
Unfortunately, however, in 2017 due to the deadlines and the fact that the company has replaced the contracts as soon as possible after the determination of its illegality, it actually came to payments from the contract.
3.20.18 and 3.20.19.
The B'ro accepts the comments and reiterates that these problems can be seen as a result of the lack of resources and the shortcomings in internal control and management, which the Court calls all in its report.
3.20.23.-3.20.25.
As the Court notes in its report, an internal investigation of this matter is currently taking place.
3.20.29.-3.20.31.
3.20.32.
On the last paragraph of the report (43), the Bureau has certain doubts as it carried out its activities in 2016 in accordance with the agreements with DG BUDG.
The B-ro has consulted DG BUDG on this matter in order to clarify this matter again and will take action immediately if DG BUDG should change its previously communicated position.

C 434/130 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 Year 2015 2016 2016 State of adoption of correction (completed/in progress/outgoing/n.z.) Completed (1) Completed (2) ANNEX Follow-up of observations from previous years Court's comments The Court established various reasons which affect the transparency of the procurement procedures, such as the lack of a clear link with the Centre's annual work programme, insufficient support for the estimated contract value or the lack of a financial benchmark for assessing the tenderer's financial capacity.
In May 2015, the Interim Director of the Centre was appointed by a decision of the Management Board.
As of 31 December 2016, this vacancy exceeded the maximum period of one year by eight months provided for in the Staff Regulations.
This also led to 15 other transitional arrangements for other staff.
In its October 2016 audit report, the Commission's Internal Audit Service (IAS) pointed out that despite the Centre's ongoing efforts to strengthen its internal controls on procurement, there are still significant obstacles to procurement.
The IAS concluded that the planning and monitoring of procurement procedures are weak and that procurement procedures are not always covered by the annual work programme or financing decision.
In addition, reference is made to the Court's report on the annual accounts 2015 of the Centre and to the established organs that affect the transparency of the procurement procedures.
The Centre and IAS agreed on a plan for corrective measures.
As in previous years, the rate of committed appropriations for Title III (operational expenditure) for the following financial year was high at 7.9 million euros and 41% (2015: 7.5 million euros and 42%).
The funding transfers were primarily linked to several-year projects in the fields of scientific advice (2.4 million euros), monitoring (1.3 million euros), public health training (1.4 million euros) and IT applications for public health (2.1 million euros).
The Centre may use separate budgetary resources to better accommodate the multi-annual nature of the activities and inevitable delays between contract signings, deliveries and payments.
(1) (2) Following a selection procedure, the Interim Director was appointed Director in 2017.
The Centre has introduced new IT tools to improve planning and monitoring of procurement procedures.

3.22.8.
In order to ensure the independence of the accountant, the formal requirement set out in the EFSA financial regulations will be implemented by EFSA in the following ways: The current accountant was appointed by the EFSA Board of Directors in 2008.
The accounting officer is under the responsibility of the Head of the BuS Division. To ensure the functional independence of the accounting officer in the procedures for assessment of performance, the Head of the BuS Division acts as the assessor and the Chairman of the Audit Committee as the countersigned staff.
The accounting officer may be removed from office at any time by the Management Board, either temporarily or definitively.
3.22.9.
There is no obligation to use the model of individual invitations to tender on the question of individual invitations to tender for framework contracts awarded in the cascade system, and both models may be suitable according to the relevant scenario.
EFSA believes that individual calls for standard services to be re-opened to competition are more appropriate and used in EFSA's statistical services, systematic review of literature and target group research.
EFSA uses the cascade model in the fall when a long-term contractual relationship is in the foreground.
In particular, in the case of the framework agreement for external inspection services, the main objective is (i) to ensure an appropriate understanding of EFSA's activities, (ii) to ensure a cohesive testing method and (iii) to ensure credibility at all administrative levels.
EFSA has control over the budget for proposals made by the contractor in the cascade system.
3.22.10.
EFSA will implement the Action Plan for the Evaluation of Regulated Products/Assessment Phase of the Authorisation of Slurry Control following IAD.

3.23.7.
The following remarks do not call into question the Court's judgment. COMMENTS ON LEGAL ACTIVITY AND ORDER OF THE PROJECT 3.23.8.
The Institute was the defendant at the end of the financial year 2017 in four disputes relating to three procurement procedures brought before the Court by rejected bidders.
In each of these cases, the applicant applied for annulment of the award decision and for compensation.
The claim for compensation in these four cases amounts to EUR 700 000 or 9% of the Institute's annual budget.
According to the evaluation of the Institute's external attorney, a reduction of EUR 75 000 (or 1% of the Institute's annual budget) was recorded to cover the expected losses.
The judgment of the Court of First Instance in each of these cases will determine the legality and regularity of the award procedures for these contracts and future payments.
In 2016, the Institute launched an open call for travel services.
The performance descriptions and the evaluation process did not provide a sufficient guarantee for the best price-performance ratio.
The formula and the pricing mechanism were not appropriate as they did not allow for an appropriate evaluation of the tenders submitted by the tenderers.
The framework agreement was concluded over a maximum duration of four years and a maximum amount of 700 000 euros.
In 2017, payments of EUR 137 000 were made in H.A. Hehe.
3.23.10.
The agencies should establish a common framework for electronic storage and exchange of data with third parties involved in procurement procedures (180) (181). As a requirement also applies to the EU institutions, the Commission is currently developing an IT summary covering all stages of public procurement procedures. It launched tools for electronic invoicing (2010), the electronic publication of documents on contract notices in the Official Journal of the EU (2011) and the electronic submission of tenders (2015).
According to the Commission, the Institute had introduced electronic invoicing for certain procedures by the end of 2017, but not the electronic tendering and submission of tenders.
3.23.11.
The Institute publishes job advertisements on its own website and in social media, but not on the website of the European Office for Personnel Selection (EPSO), which would increase transparency and publicity and enable the citizens to view job advertisements issued by the various European institutions and agencies.

Management of advisory services 3.24.15.
In the previous year, the Agency managed advisory services. Amongst other things, two selected projects for the implementation of the Pharmacovigilance Regulation (Regulation (EU) No 1027/2012 of the European Parliament and of the Council (189) and the Regulation on clinical trials (Regulation (EU) No 536/ 2014 of the European Parliament and of the Council (190)), which required the development of complex EU-wide networks, were necessary for the extensive technical IT developments.
Since the number of posts in the Agency's establishment plan was not increased, which would enable it to build up the necessary expertise internally, the Agency drew on consulting firms for the completion of these tasks.
However, the use of consulting firms has led to the agency being dependent on this external expertise in a critical manner.
3.24.16.
In order to get the projects back under their control, the agency determined which functions should not be assigned externally, but should be perceived internally.
Furthermore, the agency goes on to award consultant contracts no longer according to the criteria of time and resources, but on a fixed price basis.
It also set up a more appropriate procedure for the approval of project changes.
3.24.17.
It will take time to reduce the critical nature of the agency of consultancy firms, and the impact of the measures taken will only be apparent over the years.
One of the two large projects discussed in 2016, the pharmacovigilance project (EudraVigilance database on unexplored drug effects), was completed in 2017 with additional costs of around 0.5 million euros.
The clinical trials project is still under way. No time has been set for commissioning, but the budget was raised by another 4.9 million euros in 2017 (191).

30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/145 EN ANNEX Follow-up to comments from previous years Statements by the Court In the regulation on the fees of the Agency, deadlines for the collection of the fees of applicants and the related payments of the Agency to the competent national authorities are specified(1). In most cases, these deadlines have not been complied with.
In 2014, the Agency conducted an administrative procedure against its IT staff.
Since the introduction of a new IT accounting system in 2011, reporting on the work done in relation to the obligations and on the execution is not sufficiently transparent.
The agency concluded agreements with 25 hotels in London on business tariffs for the accommodation of experts without carrying out a competitive procurement procedure.
The six agreements on commercial tariffs and the 2016 payments based on these agreements in the amount of around 2.1 million euros are therefore contrary to the rules.
In 2014, the Commission concluded a framework agreement on behalf of more than 50 EU institutions and bodies (including the Agency) with a contractor on the acquisition of software and licenses, as well as related IT maintenance and advisory services.
In 2016, a total of 8.9 million euros were paid to the contractor of the framework contract.
The Agency did not systematically compare the calculated prices and quotations with the offers of the suppliers and did not systematically control the invoices issued to the contractor of the framework contract.
C 434/146 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 EN Court observations Since 2014, the Agency has been fundamentally restructured twice, with high and medium-sized management positions being redeployed internally.
The reassignment of key IT and administration staff has not been successful, and the agency and its activities have been exposed to a significant risk of instability.
Furthermore, there is no system for the analysis of available skills, for the identification of gaps and for the recruitment and assignment of suitable employees.
Year 2016 State of adoption of the correction (completed/in progress/outstanding/n.z.)Completed 2016 Consulting services In addition to the annual work carried out for all agencies, the Court analysed how the Agency used advisory services within the framework of two major projects.
The Parliament and the Council have entrusted the Agency with the implementation of the Regulation on pharmacovigilance (Regulation (EU) No 1027/2012) and the Regulation on clinical trials (Regulation (EU) No 536/2014), which requires the development of complex EU-wide networks.
These tasks were transferred to the Agency at a time when it was expected to reduce its staff in accordance with the Interinstitutional Agreement on budgetary discipline of 2 December 2013.
The number of posts in the Agency's establishment plan has not been increased, which would enable it to acquire the necessary expertise in business and IT development.
Extensive use of external consultants Since the agency only had more than 13 employees in its IT delivery department, it used the services of consulting companies in the areas of business analysis, information technology, project management and quality assurance.
In the second quarter of 2016, 131 local consultants and 60 other consultants were involved.
The agency has therefore been dependent on external expertise since the start of the projects in critical form, but does not adopt a strategy that regulates the use of consultants.
Insufficient control over project development and implementation When the Agency was entrusted with the new tasks in 2012 and 2014, it did not have an adequate method for managing projects in this framework.
In 2014, a new method was introduced, which had to be considerably pr-ziziert in September 2016.

In 2016, payments of €35 310 were made in hhe.
In its January 2016 audit report, the Commission's Internal Audit Service (IAS) stressed the need for the Observatory to improve the management of IT projects.
In particular, IAS concluded that a long-term strategic overall vision for the IT systems supporting the Centre's central operational operations was lacking, that the Centre's IT project management methodology was only partially adapted to its needs, and that the process of managing system requirements was inadequate.
The Observatory and IAS agreed on a plan for corrective measures.
EN C 434/152 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 REPLY OF THE OBSERVATION CENTRE 3.25.8. The Centre considers that the current organisational structure did not affect the independence of its accountants.
This independence was ensured in accordance with the relevant rules, in particular by the appointment of the auditors by the Management Board of the Observatory, the functional reporting and accountability of these auditors against the Management Board and the proper compliance with the rules on the separation of the tasks of the various financial actors of the Observatory.
In this context, the Centre is prepared to comply with the Court's recommendation, ensuring that the appropriate measures are in an appropriate position to the size of the organisation and that the effectiveness and efficiency of its operation are maintained.
3.25.9.
The Centre will also make its job advertisements known by means of the dissemination of information about the members of its governing bodies, the national contact points involved in Reitox and the other EU agencies.
In addition, the Centre's next selection process is also published on the agency's cross-cutting job vacancies portal; the network of EU agencies has developed this joint online platform to ensure that agencies' recruitment procedures are perceived publicly.
In this context, the Centre will present the cost-benefit ratio of an additional publication on the EPSO portal.
The Observatory meets the requirements of electronic procurement procedures in line with the EU legal framework and the timetable established for the introduction of electronic procurement procedures in the EU.
As early as August 2015, the Centre set up, in cooperation with the relevant services of the European Commission, the technical configuration/ICT tool, which is required for electronic invoicing (and provided by DG DIGIT to the European Commission for the implementation of DG DIGIT's framework contracts).
In addition, the Observatory planned the preparatory measures necessary to implement the modules of the electronic call for tenders and the electronic submission of tenders according to the provisions of the aforementioned legal framework from October 2018.
The implementation of this plan is underway and the Observatory assumes that it will meet this deadline without major problems.

COMMENTS ON THE EFFECTIVENESS OF BUDGETARY CURRENCY AND SERVICES 3.26.8. In 2017, the Agency had difficulty in reaching a sufficient number of tenderers in several medium-value procurement procedures.
3.26.9.
The Agency is currently managing three dedicated, non-integrated IT systems (SIS II, VIS and Eurodac), all of which process data on the EU's policy area of freedom, security and justice.
This approach could prevent the Agency from achieving economies of scale and synergies between the different systems.
The current considerations of extending the Agency's mandate over the coming years to the management of several additional IT systems underpin the increasing urgency of this problem.
The Agency should, in consultation with the Commission and the Member States, draw up a detailed cost-benefit analysis to contribute to a discussion on the future development strategy for the systems.
3.26.10.
The project for the construction of a new building at the site in Stra§burg was considerably delayed.
Although the Agency had already paid the full price for the construction work in 2016, these were still not completed at the end of 2017 and the progress reports on the work that had been done covered only around 70% of the work.
Some of the agency's staff have already taken over the new building, although the work was still ongoing.
The agency and the contractor blame each other for the delays. In December 2017, the contractor made financial demands on the agency and filed a complaint.
The agency exercises its own legal claim against the contractor (205).
3.26.11.
3.26.12.
In accordance with its framework financial regulation, the agencies should establish a uniform solution for the electronic storage and exchange of data with third parties involved in procurement procedures (206) (207). As a corresponding requirement also applies for the EU institutions, the Commission is currently developing an IT comprehensive solution covering all stages of public procurement procedures. It launched tools for electronic invoicing (2010), the electronic publication of documents for contract notices in the Official Journal of the EU (2011) and the electronic submission of tenders (2015).
Advice 3.26.13.
Due to the nature of its activities, the Agency uses consulting services mainly in connection with IT projects.
According to the Agency's records, IT projects were implemented in 2017 within the financial and time frame.
For the few developmental maintenance projects that complain somewhat behind the schedule, exceptional reports were written.
(205) See also the Agency's 2017 annual accounts, Section 2.1.5 ăEvents after the closing date. (206) Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) No 1271/2013, Article 79 Electronic Administration (ăe-Government).
(207) Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 966/2012, Article 95(2) Electronic Administration (ăe-Government),
EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/155 3.26.14.
The Agency uses a outsourcing model for the development and implementation of IT projects, in which around 90% of the corresponding work is carried out by contractors.
There are three main framework agreements with three consortia, one for each system.
Payments to these framework agreements in 2017 amounted to EUR 3 million for Eurodac, EUR 16 million for SIS II and EUR 13 million for VIS.
Although all phases of the IT projects, from the definition of requirements and milestones to the commissioning of new system components, are owned and controlled by the Agency, a model in which the development capabilities for such sensitive IT systems are outsourced to this extent carries considerable risks with regard to a superior dependence of the contractors.
This is all the more true in view of the limited number of potential contractors from operational and security considerations that can deal with systems of this size and these requirements.
3.26.15.
At the same time, the low number of staff in operational key offices, especially in the ăReferat for Application Management and Maintenance (AMM), carries a significant risk for the continuity of the operation.
In the second half of 2017, the head of the AMM unit temporarily held the position of head of the ăOperative department and the post of head of the ăReferat for operation and infrastructure, thus uniting the three highest management positions in the Operational department, which carries further risks for the continuity.
3.26.16.
The framework agreements concluded with the respective consortia for the operation of the main IT systems include not only normal maintenance but also development maintenance work, the price of which cannot be calculated on the basis of the cost estimates attached to the framework agreements.
The prices for the individual contracts are calculated by the Agency on the basis of a combination of fixed price and estimate of the time and resources spent, thus aiming for a sound cost control.
For the VIS contract, the agency also relied on the IFPUG(208) method, a standard method based on the function point analysis for determining the prices of developmental abilities.
The agency could also use the IFPUG method for other systems in development.
COMMENTS ON BUDGETARY CURRENCY 3.26.17.
The Agency made global commitments of EUR 69.9 million in total to cover future expenditure on new tasks and IT systems, which were originally to be transferred to it in 2017, but for which the legal basis had not yet been adopted by the end of the year (Eurodac recast and allocation system to Dublin) or only shortly before (Regulation on the Entry/Exit System of 30 November 2017).
The corresponding appropriations for payments were reduced by two amending budgets of EUR 85.6 million, from EUR 153.3 million in the original budget to EUR 85.6 million in the final budget.

EN C 434/168 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 REPLY OF THE AGENCY 3.28.8.
Europol employs over 220 liaison officers from EU Member States and third countries and organisations.
The common working language of Europol is English. Therefore, Europol's internal language arrangements adopted by the Management Board lay down that, unless otherwise agreed, recruitment procedures should be carried out in English.
For this reason, Europol's job advertisements are published in English.
Europol has an effective and transparent recruitment process with a vacancy rate of 0% at the end of 2017. In the 89 recruitment procedures carried out in 2017, there were an average of 58 candidates per selection process.
For the publication on the website of the European Personnel Selection Office (EPSO), the translation into the EU official languages is required in addition to the English version.
Due to the high number of job offers per year, translation into EU official languages would entail high costs and the duration of the procedures would be longer.
Europol focuses on operational needs in budgetary expenditure, which is why job advertisements are translated into all EU official languages, including EPSO publication, only in certain cases (e.g. the Executive Director or Deputy Executive Directors).

In addition, the Agency has limited resources for these measures.
In future calls for proposals of this kind, however, the Agency will consider carrying out market research, possibly over-examine the technical requirements and, if possible, reassess the priority of the studies to be carried out.
Nevertheless, this problem is much easier to solve if more resources are used for operational expenditure.
The Agency started to implement such systems in 2018, which will be available within the set deadline.
EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/173 3.30.
EUROPEAN AGENCY FOR THE FRONTEX INTRODUCTION 3.30.1.
The European Agency for Border and Coast Guard (hereinafter referred to as the Agency), was established by Regulation (EU) 2016/1624 of the European Parliament and of the Council (228) (the new Guarantee Regulation), repealing Council Regulation (EC) No 2007/2004 (229).
It has been expanded on the basis of the European Agency for the Development of Operational Cooperation at the external borders of the Member States, maintaining the abbreviation "Frontex" and the Warsaw headquarters.
The new regulation extends the Agency's mandate and gives the Agency the task of ensuring an integrated border management at the external borders at European level in order to effectively manage the crossing of external borders.
This includes the fight against migratory pressure and potential future threats at these borders, while at the same time contributing to the fight against serious crime with a cross-border dimension in order to ensure a high level of internal security within the Union, while fully respecting fundamental rights and respect for freedom of movement in this area.

Note 3.30.7.
The Agency's expenditure on financial assistance increased significantly from EUR 123 million (2016) to EUR 167 million (2017).
Unlike in previous years, the Agency did not carry out ex-post checks on the reimbursement of expenditure related to financial assistance in 2017.
It considers that the ex ante inspections carried out prior to reimbursement have been improved and now as soon as they reach a certain amount of time, they provide the necessary security.
However, the Court has repeatedly reported since 2014 that the cooperating States often do not prove the expenditure they claim to be insufficient, which was again the case in this case (see points 3.30.12-3.30.13).
3.30.8.
In 2016, the Court recommended that the Agency identify the most appropriate financing mechanism in an in-depth analysis (233).
In this context, the Court notes that the Board of Directors decided at the end of 2017 to use unit costs instead of reimbursement of actual costs for operational activities.
At the same time, a pilot project was launched in 2018 to determine the unit costs for resources sent from cooperating states.
In addition, in June 2017, the Board of Directors approved a new organisational structure of the Agency, which will take effect from 2018 and includes the creation of a new inspection and control body, which will report directly to the Executive Director and the Board of Directors in order to adapt the previous organisation to the new mandate (see point 3.30.9).
3.30.9.
In view of the migration crisis facing the Union, the Agency's mandate was significantly expanded in 2016.
The Agency's budget was increased by 75% in 2016 and the budget for 2017 was again 21% higher than in the previous year.
The staff increased by 18% in 2016 and by an additional 43% compared to the previous year.
The adaptation of the systems and procedures to the new mandate and the new circumstances is still in progress.
The following remarks do not call into question the Court's judgment and are to be read against the background of the challenges that the Agency had to address.
COMMENTS ON THE LEGALITY AND ORDER OF THE PROPOSALS 3.30.10.
Following an open call for proposals, the Agency received four offers of guidance services for the promotion of migrants within Greece.
After the selection criteria were examined, three offers were retained and one was excluded.
The only criterion for the award was the price.
In April 2017, the Agency signed a framework agreement of EUR 2 million for a period of three years with the company that had offered the lowest price.
However, the contractor's funding facilities were limited from time to time and he had problems fulfilling the contract, so that the agency cancelled the contract at the end of 2017.
In order to ensure continuity of services, the Agency for the remaining period signed a new framework agreement of EUR 1.8 million with the second-ranked bidder, who had offered the second lowest price in November 2017.
It did not negotiate the terms of this replacement contract with the tenderers ranked second and third, but signed the new contract on the basis of the original bid submitted by the second-placed tenderer.
The direct award of the replacement was contrary to the rules, as the original award procedure was completed and a negotiated procedure for agreeing the terms of the contract, which would apply until the conclusion of a new open procedure, was not carried out.
No payments were made for this replacement order in 2017.
3.30.11.
The Staff Regulations provide that, in the case of an external selection procedure, temporary staff shall be recruited only in grades SC 1 to SC 2, AST 1 to AST 4 or AD 5 to AD 8 (234).
In 2017, the Agency hired two staff members (2016: 14) in higher AST grades.

EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/175 COMMENTS ON INTERNAL CONTROLS 3.30.12.
In 2017, the Agency of the Icelandic Coast Guard received financial support in connection with the deployment of an aircraft in Greece.
Before reimbursement of expenditure claimed by Iceland, the Agency requested invoices as proof of a category of expenditure declared.
Although the invoices were never submitted, the Agency reimbursed around EUR 440 000.
In this case, the ex ante over-prevention was therefore ineffective.
3.30.13.
The Agency also co-financed the use of an aircraft used by the Spanish Guardia Civil.
In the absence of supporting documents for the costs claimed for inspection and maintenance work, the Agency reimbursed 430 000 euros on the basis of average costs per flight hour.
These average costs were calculated on the basis of cost ceilings used in trades between the Spanish authorities and private contractors for inspection and maintenance work.
There is a risk that higher costs have been reimbursed than actually incurred.
3.30.14.
Although the Agency has already moved into its current accounts in 2014, it has still not drawn up a comprehensive contingency plan approved by the Management Board.
COMMENTS ON BUDGETARY CURRENCY 3.30.15.
The Agency again cancelled a large amount of committed appropriations carried over from the previous year for the reimbursement of expenditure incurred by states participating in joint actions, amounting to EUR 7.7 million or 16.5% (2016: EUR 5.6 million or 17.6%).
This shows that the cooperating States had again clearly overestimated the expenses to be reimbursed by the Agency.
Although funds transferred for joint actions had to be cancelled in two consecutive years, in 2017 the Agency transferred €9.6 million from other budget lines to joint actions, once again transferring an amount of €40,5 million to the following financial year.
Joint actions represent 69% of the total amount cancelled in 2017 (EUR 11.1 million) and 46% of the total amount transferred in 2018 (EUR 87.6 million).
3.30.16.
In 2017, 66.5 million euros were spent on return operations. However, fewer actions were carried out than funds were available.
The Agency therefore paid back to the Commission EUR 13.5 million or 20.3% (2016: EUR 23 million or 37.5%).
In addition, the Agency paid EUR 4 million of the budget estimates under Title I of the budget (staff expenditure) back, as not as many new employees could be hired as planned in 2017.
3.30.17.
The Agency's original budget for 2017 included 8.8 million euros for the required operational financial default to finance immediate operations for border management purposes and return operations (235).
However, in September and again in October 2017, the Agency transferred 1.9 million euros (totaling 3.8 million euros) from the reserve to its operational budget in order to finance other activities.
3.30.18.
After the implementation of transfers from other budget lines and the establishment of an amending budget, the appropriations entered in the reserve amounted to 24.7 million euros and 8.1% of the original budget.
The Agency, however, used the reserve mainly to finance standard operations (8.4 million euros) and to finance a project for remote air surveillance (drones, 7 million euros), for which it had estimated only 1.1 million euros.
The estimation and use of unmandable complaints is incompatible with the principle of the speciality budget and concerns the transparency of the budget.
